definitions.definition: to look quickly but not very carefully at a document, etc.
definitions.sensetop: scan something for somethingscan somethingscan through something (for something)scan for something

examples.text: I scanned the list quickly for my name.
She scanned through the newspaper over breakfast.
You should teach students to scan for essential information.
I scanned the paper for news.
He scanned through the web pages.

definitions.definition: to look at every part of something carefully, especially because you are looking for a particular thing or person

examples.text: He scanned the horizon for any sign of land.
She scanned the room for an empty seat.
She scanned the street nervously, looking for the two men.

definitions.definition: to pass light over a picture or document using a scanner in order to copy it and put it in the memory of a computer

examples.text: How do I scan a photo and attach it to an email?
This recognizes text in a scanned image.
The pencil image is scanned into a computer.

definitions.definition: to get an image of an object, a part of somebody’s body, etc. on a computer by passing X-rays, ultrasound waves or electromagnetic waves over it in a special machine

examples.text: Their brains are scanned so that researchers can monitor the progress of the disease.
Concealed video cameras scan every part of the compound.

definitions.definition: to examine a computer program or document in order to look for a virus

examples.text: This software is designed to scan all new files for viruses.

definitions.definition: to have a regular rhythm according to fixed rules

wordOrigin: late Middle English (as a verb in sense (5)): from Latin scandere ‘climb’ (in late Latin ‘scan (verses)’), by analogy with the raising and lowering of one's foot when marking rhythm. From ‘analyse (metre)’ arose the senses ‘estimate the correctness of’ and ‘examine minutely’, which led to ‘look at searchingly’ (late 18th cent.).
